Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will continue the research by PI James E. Dixon to continue underwater paleoenvironmental modeling and archaeological survey in Southeast Alaska as part of a multi-year effort to identify ancient archaeological remains on the continental shelf dating to the late Pleistocene, ca 12,000-16,000 y.a. This is the time period when sea level was lower, due to the ice sheets covering large parts of North America. During this time period, the coastline had the potential for supporting human occupation and it has long been hypothesized that this was one of the routes of early human migration from Asia to North America. Following the flooding that occurred with the post-Pleistocene sea level rise, evidence of these early migrations,in the form of archeological sites, would have been covered and now occupying the contemporary sea floor.

The previous project, Gateway to America I, was supported though a Small Grant for Exploratory Research through the Arctic Social Sciences Program. During that pilot project, two anomalies in the undersea area were discovered; one resembling a stone fishing weir, the other a rectangular and circular shaped depresses that could be of cultural origin. This project would continue the investigation started in the pilot project by 1) documenting and testing the anomalies observed in 2010, and 2) conducting additional underwater survey and testing guided by GIS modeling and field observations. The project has the potential to bring empirical evidence to a decades old debate in North American archaeology: when and by what route did people migrate into North America from Asia?

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the Earth's last geologic epoch, the Quaternary, the formation of continental glaciers resulted in vast amounts of water being transferred from the oceans to the land in the form of glacial ice.  The most recent event, or Last Glacial Maximum (LGM), peaked about 19,000 years ago when global sea level was lowered by about 120 meters (394 feet). This event exposed the relatively shallow seabed, or continental shelf, along the margins of the world's continents.

Along the Northwest (NW) Coast of North America isolated areas of unglaciated land supported terrestrial plants and animals during the LGM.  Fish, birds and marine mammals inhabited the adjacent coastal waters and shores. As the glacial ice retreated, terrestrial plants and animals colonized the newly exposed land.  About 17,000-16,000 years ago these events created a coastal corridor bordered on the west by the Pacific Ocean and on the east by the massive Cordilleran ice sheet.

This corridor may have been the first viable route for human migration from Asia to North America.  This suggests that North America's earliest archeological sites may lie beneath the sea on the continental shelf of the NW Coast.  Although some sites were likely destroyed or disturbed by the encroaching sea, other evidence suggests that some were preserved and remain to be discovered. As sea level rose, coastal people were displaced as their former habitation sites were flooded when the ice sheets melted.

This project focused on the continental shelf in SE Alaska's Alexander Archipelago to: 1) define submerged locales exhibiting high potential for archeological site discovery using computer modeling and bathymetric analyses of geomorphic features, 2) conduct geophysical survey to focus field testing within high potential areas, 3) sample specific high potential features within the survey areas, and 4) analyze and report the results of the submerged landscape modeling and archeological survey. Underwater survey was conducted during the summers of 2012-14.  Limited on-shore survey and data analysis and report preparation continued throughout 2015-16. A supplemental award to this project supported the continued analysis and publication of research conducted at Shuka' Ka'a Cave, located on Prince of Wales Island in SE Alaska throughout 2017-19.

Field research was conducted using global positioning systems, sub-bottom profiling, side-scan and multibeam sonar, magnetometer survey, and a remotely operated underwater vehicle (ROV).  High potential areas were examined using the ROV and bottom sampling technology to test ancient submerged landscape features. A total of 129 locales were identified and subject to sub-surface testing by suction dredging and Van Veen grab sampling.  The recovered sediment was water screened on board ship for artifacts and other indicators of human occupation.

No definitive evidence of human occupation was discovered under water. However, archeological evidence from Shuka' Ka'a Cave and other archeological sites demonstrate human occupation of adjacent areas when sea level was lower.  Three radiocarbon dates run on wood recovered approximately 56 meters below sea level in the Gulf of Esquibel dated to approximately 11,500 years ago.  These and other data demonstrate that submerged late Pleistocene geomorphic features containing preserved organic remains can be identified, sampled, and dated. Additional refinement is necessary to develop higher precision bathymetric analyses, submerged landscape modeling, and land-sea level relationships to more precisely focus sampling.

This project provided support and experiential educational opportunities for five University of New Mexico graduate students, one Ph.D. dissertation, a postdoctoral fellow, and college credit for a Native American intern from the University of Alaska, Juneau to participate in submerged landscape archeology. The continued analyses of Shuka' Ka'a Cave also has provided the first opportunity to characterize the genetic and physical characteristics and associated technology of the earliest known inhabitants of the NW Coast. The results of this research have been disseminated through seven national and international journal publications or juried conference presentations, one monograph, two book chapters, fourteen conference presentations, and one Ph.D. dissertation. A substantive monograph documenting and interpreting the excavations of Shuka' Ka'a Cave is nearing publication.  The Aurora Monograph Series of the Alaska Anthropological Association will publish it as both an open access and hard copy publication.

The U.S. lags behind other industrialized nations in recognizing importance of submerged landscape archeology and its relevance to understanding human response to rising sea level, the origins of maritime adaptations, species dispersals, climate change, and the underwater research needed to address these important scientific questions. This project advanced submerged landscape archeology by advancing the theoretical, methodological, and technological protocols for archeological research on the continental shelves. As the demand for economic resources continues to expand to the world's continental shelves, it will become becoming increasingly important to locate and evaluate submerged archeological sites and preserve the valuable scientific and cultural heritage information they contain.
